awd_titl_txt: ICE-T: RC: Horizontal Resource Management in Distributed Edge Clouds
awd_abstract_narration:
The latency, bandwidth, and mobility needs of the next-generation Internet of Things (IoT), smart wearables, and augmented reality applications and devices makes traditional cloud platforms ill-suited to their needs. Edge cloud computing, where computational and storage resources are deployed at the edge of the network and offered through a cloud model, has emerged as a promising alternative to address the needs of these emerging applications.

This project examines network-aware horizontal resource management in edge clouds and will focus on three synergistic topics. First, the team will design network-aware orchestration algorithms for edge clouds, including new edge cloud migration technique that combines multi-path transport and virtual machine migration to provide network-transparent low-latency access in the face of user and device mobility.  Second, the team will study network-aware placement in distributed edge clouds that incorporates the application's latency and bandwidth needs while being aware of interacting distributed edge and virtualized network functions. Third, the project research will address the fundamental issue of the control plane architecture for massively distributed edge clouds and will study both decentralized and hierarchical control plane architectures for future edge clouds. The project team will study the tradeoffs and benefits of both architectures through the lens of orchestration algorithms such as geo-elastic scaling algorithms as well as edge migration and network-aware placement. Our research will also involve prototype implementation and large-scale experimentation on multiple experimental research testbeds.

This project will extend a collaboration between the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, and Umea University, Sweden.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on a US-EU collaboration between the University of Massachusetts Amherst  and multiple universities in Sweden to address cross-disciplinary challenges in designing next-generation edge and cloud computing. The collaborative research resulted in new cloud resource management techniques to ensure web-based  cloud services provide low-latency performance to their users  in the presence of dynamically changing workloads.  The collaboration yielded a new technique called resource deflation that provides a more flexible approach for reclaiming unused resources from cloud application during times of resource pressure so that these reclaimed resources can then be reallocated to overloaded applications.  In a parallel effort, the collaborative research yielded new control theory-based approaches to dynamically adapt the number of servers allocated to a cloud-based web application in a power-efficient manner while also meeting latency needs of  the application. Finally, the project developed model-driven approaches for latency-sensitive serverless applications on edge platforms. The research  yielded queuing theory-based models to predict the latency seen by the application under different arrival rates and used this model to dynamically allocate and deallocate an appropriate number of containers for the serverless application while meeting its latency constraints. Collectively, these research results demonstrated the ability of cloud platforms to intelligently and  adaptively allocate to their applications in order to maintain good end-user performance even in the presence of dynamic workloads.

 

The broader impacts of the project involves co-supervision of graduate students from faculty members across collaborating institutions, a student exchange where Swedish graduate students visited UMass Amherst during the summer, and a collaboration with three Swedish Universities, Chalmers, Umea and Lund, and a collaboration with Ericsson Research, a Swedish telecommunication company. The project provided partial training to four PhD students, three of whom were female, and provided Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) training to two students.
